titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Julia Driver Collection of Women in Photography
Driver (Julia) Collection of Women in Photography
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:19

did.unittitle: Julia Driver collection of women in photography.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: This collection consists chiefly of 1559 photographs collected by Julie Driver that represent work by over 550 commercial women photographers, 1845-1940. The collection also includes thirty examples of cased photographs, which consist of ambrotypes and daguerreotypes, 1845-1862. The collection is rich in card photographs, especially cartes-de-visite and cabinet photographs created during the second half of the nineteenth century, as well as some other photographic print formats, items of ephemera and printed material. Nearly two-thirds of the women represented in the collection worked in the United States of America. Of the American photographers, nearly a quarter worked in Illinois or New York. Significant numbers worked in Iowa, Michigan, and Ohio. Women photographers from England and Sweden are also well-represented in the collection. Other represented nations and localities include Algeria, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Egypt, Finland, France, Tahiti, Germany, Ireland, Japan, Malta, Norway, Scotland, Spain, Switzerland, and Wales.

langmaterial.language: Benchmarks and captions in English, Swedish, Finnish, German, and French.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Julia Driver Collection of Women in Photography is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Julia Driver Collection of Women in Photography. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Much of the biographical information derives from research by Julia Driver.

bioghist.head: Julia Driver (born 1961)
bioghist.p: Julia Driver is a collector of photography. She is also a philosopher with research interests in normative ethical theory and moral psychology. Her works include Uneasy Virtue (2001) and Ethics: The Fundamentals (2005).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists chiefly of 1559 photographs collected by Julie Driver that represent work by over 550 commercial women photographers, 1845-1940. The collection also includes thirty examples of cased photographs, which consist of ambrotypes and daguerreotypes, 1845-1862. The collection is rich in card photographs, especially cartes-de-visite and cabinet photographs created during the second half of the nineteenth century, as well as some other photographic print formats, items of ephemera and printed material. Nearly two-thirds of the women represented in the collection worked in the United States of America. Of the American photographers, nearly a quarter worked in Illinois or New York. Significant numbers worked in Iowa, Michigan, and Ohio. Women photographers from England and Sweden are also well-represented in the collection. Other represented nations and localities include Algeria, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Egypt, Finland, France, Tahiti, Germany, Ireland, Japan, Malta, Norway, Scotland, Spain, Switzerland, and Wales.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: Series I. Cased Photographs, 1845-1962. Series II. Card Photographs and Other Photographic Materials, 1845-1940.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is arranged alphabetically by the surname of the photographer or the corporate name of the studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of daguerreotypes and ambrotypes primarily in contemporary glass mats and decorative cases that document the work of women photographers and their partnerships. If known, each entry in this guide includes the life dates of the photographer, the locations active, work dates, and known aliases.

did.unittitle: Card Photographs and Other Photographic Materials

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Photographic Materials; Photographic Materials by Men; and Oversize Photographic Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic materials, chiefly card photographs in the form of cartes-de-visite and cabinet photographs, as well as some variant styles of card photographs and other photographic print formats. There are also some scattered items of ephemera and printed material. The series documents work by over five hundred women photographers or their partnerships from the middle of the nineteenth century to the turn of the twentieth century. Only the work of Minnie F. Libby is referenced in multiple subseries.

The subjects for the majority of images are not documented in this series. However, descriptions include names of identified individuals, as well as notes concerning unique subject matter. Subjects include wedding portraits, studio portrait that include animals, exterior views, and portraits of children dressed for baptisms and confirmations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of vintage photographic prints, chiefly cartes-de-visite and cabinet photographs, but also including some other card photographs, tintypes, and ephemera. Photographic materials with dimensions larger than 22 x 29 cm (8.7 x 11.4 in.) are located in the Oversize Photographic Materials subseries

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by the surname of the photographer or the corporate name of the studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a carte-de-visite portrait of Omer Huff (born circa 1837)
Stereographs of Waterloo, New York include interior and exterior views of the Towsley House Hotel; interior views of the Saint John Chapel, and discrete views of Saint Paul's Church and Main Street
Several stereographs depict Minerva Cornell with a model of the residence of Reverend Henry G. Dewitt (born 1835) in Canandaigua, New York, which she made from seashells.
Two stereographs depict a memorial floral display for Anna Hollenbach (died 1885).
Another stereograph is a copy photograph of a bird's eye lithograph engraving of the Willard Asylum for the Chronic Insane in Willard, New York
